newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean economy seen recovering but at slow pace.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean economy seen recovering but at slow pace.

text.p: South Korea's central bank on Monday forecast economic growth would accelerate to 6.3 percent in the second half of this year, boosted by rising exports and construction investment.

The Bank of Korea (BOK) said in a report that the export-led economy would benefit from both an improving world economy and the yen's strength, which should allow Korean exports to be more competitive in the region.
"The worst is over. The economy will improve in the second half, but only at a slow pace," said Park Jung-kyu, a central bank economist.
Gross domestic product (GDP) rose by 5.6 percent in the first half of 1997.
The central bank also revised its full-year current-account deficit forecast to $17 billion from an earlier projection of $18 billion.
The deficit includes a $9.5 billion invisible trade shortfall this year.
Slowing wage rises, weeks of strikes over labour reforms and a slew of corporate debt defaults dampened consumption and corporate investment in the first half of the year.
This prompted the BOK to revise its growth forecast for the whole of 1997 down to 6.0 percent from 6.4 percent projected in November.
Kim Ju-hyung, director of the LG Economic Research Institute, said he expected further signs of recovery to emerge in the third quarter.
"But this time, hitting the bottom does not mean a quick recovery. The economy is expected to show a gradual "U-shaped" turnaround," said Cho Hong-rae, an economist at Hyundai Research Institute.

Some economists believe the central bank's projections on growth are too optimistic. Lee Han-koo, president of Daewoo Economic Research Institute, said the bank appeared to have based its optimism on rising export prices.
"The impact from a strong yen would be limited," Lee said. "I would caution against the central bank's optimism."
Daewoo has forecast 5.5 percent GDP growth for the whole of 1997 and Hyundai Economic Research Institute 5.9 percent.
Goldman Sachs puts growth at 5.3 percent this year, while LG is more optimistic with a projection of between 6.1 and 6.2 percent growth.
Lim Choon-soo, head of research at Goldman Sachs, cautioned against what he described as a mood of "euphoria" over the recent improvement in economic data seen in the past few months.
The country's customs-cleared trade deficit showed a surplus of $97.6 million in June, the first monthly surplus in 30 months.

The central bank said it expected a 15 percent increase in the value of its exports in the July-December period year-on-year because of rising prices of key export items, such as semiconductor, steel and petrochemical products.
But Lee disagreed, saying spot prices for 16-megabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips, accounting for 17 percent of South Korea's total exports, were likely to fluctuate further.
Some economists said it was uncertain if export prices of petrochemical products would move in favour of South Korea.
Lim at Goldman Sachs said the impact from a strengthening yen would be limited as only 30 percent of South Korean exports compete with Japanese products on world markets.
"It will give a psychological boost. But the real impact will not be as big as many expect," he added.
